posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Advice on making a successful advice post on /o/:

If you are looking to get advice on a possible car purchase or car related problem, be sure to include:

What car or cars you are looking at or as detailed a description of the problem as possible. Include make, model, year, mileage, condition, any know faults, the asking price, and what your budget is!

If people have to ask you for every detail, you aren't going to get many replies!

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
1.)Get financing ahead of time/know your credit. You always want to have a financing option in hand before you go to a dealership. Nothing wrong with negotiating a better deal with them once you get there, but never go in empty handed. This way you can have idea of how much you can afford to spend, and what a car is going to cost you

2.)Do your research. Know what values KBB/NADA/Edmunds/TrueCar are listing for the cars you are interested in. Also know what other dealerships are listing similar cars for. Dealerships will prey on the uninformed, so make sure that you are

2b.)If you don't know enough about cars to inspect one yourself, arrange to get any used car inspected or bring someone who DOES know what to look for. It's surprisingly easy to polish up a turd and get it passed inexperienced eyes

3.)Never take the first offer, unless it's a place like CarMax that doesn't negotiate. Dealerships know the game, and they always get a certain number of people to bite on the first offer. make them work a little to get your business

4.)You can negotiate on more than the price. Oil changes, services plans, warranties, accessories are all fair game.

5.)In today's world, internet sales departments are your friend. You can send a blanket email to 3 or 4 dealerships and get them to compete for your business, let them haggle with each other before you ever haggle with them

6.)Get them to print you a Buyers Order for any car you are seriously, that is what you negotiate from. It will look like pic related, and itemize every line of the sale. Don't let them 4 square you or hand write shit on a piece of paper. Get a buyers order

7.)Never be afraid to walk away from a deal. If you have a bad feeling, sleep on it. There will always be other cars

posts.com:
For a while, I've had a book that lists every single Italian auto manufacturer. There's a brief section on OPES (Officine di Precisione E Stampaggio), the first new manufacturer in post-war Italy. Their only car, the Ninfea, was a FWD sedan that came with a 702cc or 784cc 3 cylinder engine. After a prototype was made in Turin in 1946, it was showcased at an auto show there in 1948. They obtained 100 orders, but financial issues caused the company to fold before they could fulfill any of them.

The only images online of it seem to come from a single brochure. Of the handful of examples made, I don't think any are extant.

>>26275735
No. It wasn't even a real serial production - it was an initiative research project by some engineers and designers of Central Scientific Research Automobile and Automotive Engines Institute (NAMI for short). Six cars that they made remained in their personal posession. All of them had air cooled V4 at the rear from different ZAZ models.
There was a noticeable movement of self-made automobiles in USSR, with conventions and articles in tech journals like "Technics for the youth". One of the most prominent of the constructors and his son are hosting YT channels "Combat Crew" and "Combat Crew Live" which has detailed videos about their projects (most famous one, Laura, is on the pic), maybe you will be able to understand something with YT subtitles. Also, one of the most popular youtubers found one of the soviet self-made cars on sale, fixed it and made an interview with the old man who made it:
https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLiCpP_44QZBz9D1Cp8f2Qp1auev7EKqpi

>>26290735
this is actually really important. Right foot always right peg and rear brake when stopped. It'll help incase you get tapped yes, but makes it so you can stop and start on inclines as well as keeping the bike locked in with your right hand free to manipulate gas incase you gotta move quickly.
Basically
>left side of lane
>left foot down
>right foot right brake
You gotta do a dance to shift back into gear if you've shifted into neutral for a long light, but its a very valuable habit to get into, and having both foot or right foot down at a light will show your newbie to other riders who will judge you.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: If anybody remembers my Ninja 250 with the dragging brakes, I took it to a mechanic and I'm glad I did. For $240 AUD he rebuilt the caliper and linished the pistons, and he even told me one of the likely causes. Apparently my eBay levers are a different shape to the OEM ones, so they apply more pressure on the forward stroke than the backwards stroke. So repeated very hard braking combined with a little bit of grit in the caliper might have made the pressure build up without a good way to release it. So it's something that I could have never really figured out or done at home. I'm going to buy some OEM-style levers from him too, because even though I'll only have this bike for a few more months I want to make sure it lasts a long time for the next owner.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26292796
I haven't ridden the DR650 but I have plenty of time on a DRZ400S and KLX300, and a little on a WR250R. The DRZ had plenty of power for roads, but the gear ratios were too close together to make a great dual sport. Either it was geared for dirt or the road, and it would suffer in whichever you didn't choose. The engine wasn't particularly smooth either.

The KLX300 and WR250R are both down on power quite a bit, but their engines are much smoother so winding them out on the road for long durations wasn't as bothersome, and gear ratios wider so they could reasonably accommodate both road and dirt riding on the same sprocket set. They also feel considerably lighter and more nimble, though the actual weight difference isn't all that big. The way they carry their weight makes them much easier to ride off road. Overall I'd say the KLX and WR make better dual sports than the DRZ.

The DR650 may be favorable if you're doing longer distance trips, especially if you'll be carrying luggage.

Distribution doesn't tell the whole story, another big factor is how far the mass sits away from the center of rotation (polar moment of inertia).
In a mid-engined car like an MR2, the mass sits very close to the center, which makes it very nimble and responsive, but prone to sudden snaps. The transaxle Porsches (924/944/968) have a heavy engine in the front and a heavy transmission in the back, which gives them a very nice 50/50 balance but also makes them very easy to keep under control. A 911 has a lot of weight way out at the back, which gives it a lot of traction but makes it pretty scary to drive at the limit with that pendulum-like rear end that just wants to keep swinging round every corner.
Subarus and longitudinal Audis have a lot of weight way out in front, which makes them resist turn-in more than other drivetrain layouts. That big engine lump wants to keep going straight most of all.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Having owned a C4 S6 and B5 S4, you can absolutely race Audis, but just know that they aren't the best chassis for it and make far better autobahn/comfy canyon road cars. Post B4/C4/D1 the cars got the famous Audi 4 link front suspension which has an immense benefit towards reducing understeer vs the MacPherson front of early cars, along with the adoption of shorter V6/V8 engines (often aluminum) vs inline 5s. Also post B7/C6 got the newer style transmissions which move the engine back about 4 inches, putting the bellhousing flange directly centered with the front axle.

Rear swaybars help a lot but in poor conditions like rain you can't increase front grip with a swaybar, only better tire selection.

tl;dr they make great fast daily drivers but there are better handling chassis out there, mostly on the basis of being lighter weight more so than being front heavy.
>>26288225
You can't compare weight distribution just as a %/%, because light weight cars always get fucked. If a B5 RS4 is ~3500 lbs, then the 500 lb engine + 200 lb transmission is a big part of that, compared to an RS6 which is ~5000 lbs with around the same engine+trans weight.

Obviously a car with more front weight is going to have a tendency towards understeer IN A RELATIVE SENSE, as in, likely the front wheels will lose grip before the rears ON THAT CAR. You can't compare %/% between cars that weigh differently.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Audis do not feel like shit on the track. I track my S6 routinely.

The weight over the front axle is real, but is less real every generation. It’s not 1985. Even the V8 in the S4 is as small as the old inline 5.

You have to understand the new corvette and the 911 C2S come with understeer dialed in from the factory because it’s safer.

Audi has poor weight distribution (so does a 911 really). But it also has maximum traction in any given scenario. The S and RS cars also have a torque splitting differential. You turn right and the outside rear wheel will overdrive and you’ll find the car oversteers when driven properly. The understeer meme is either out of date, Related to the old S3 and under or a misunderstanding of what understeer is.

You can feel the weight of the engine when you turn an Audi. Normal fags such as Doug demuro mistake this for ‘understeer’ and indeed it can contribute to understeer. But understeer does not occur unless the front tires have reach maximum traction and can no longer turn anymore and they are not turning enough. This does not occur on the street. It does not occur even in a golf R until the tires get too hot after a few laps.

The Audi S cars come with a rather aggressive -2.5 camber stock. I adjust mine to -3.0. I added a rear sway bar that’s slightly stiffer than an RS. I find the car understeers in a manageable way with the torque splitting rear diff on tap to turn in the nose of the car.
It’s very good Imo, considering it’s a street car. Yes the new corvette does not have the sensation of weight in front of you but the reality is that it understeer roughly the same as my Audi due to the nature of the suspension geometry.

Consider now as well the 911. The engine is in the back. You get better traction on the rear wheels but when the gas is applied that extra traction is taken from the front wheels. The result is understeer.

Go down the grid at an Indy or F1 race where the cars are ‘neutral’ by design and you’ll find drivers still prefer under or oversteer dialed in depending on their style.

The upside to Audi is power and traction. The downside is weight and where the weight is. Idk if Audi has ever made a light weight car. The real downside is the computer and traction management in an S car will constantly be fighting you on track in little ways. It’s too aggressive. It works very well but at the cost of your brake pads. Have to VAG com it down as much as possible.

As long as you drive an Audi like an AWD car and play to its strengths they’re excellent fun on track. But you can’t drive it like a Caymen and then complain it’s not ‘as good’. You just have to manage the weight and trail brake and hit the gas hard esrly to make the turn.

posts.com:
>>26293897
>I got caught speeding 40km over the limit. It's going to be a $750 monetary fine and 3 months disqualification
Only had to read that far to know that you're in Australia.

You have a couple of options.
>Go to court and plead that your license is necessary for employment
Honestly your chances of success with this are pretty high if you work in the trades or something where you're required to move a vehicle around between work sites and such. Effectively nil chance if you're a typical wagie with a single workplace, even lower if they determine that a public transport route exists to get you to and from work. Remember they make the rules to be punitive, not a mere inconvenience. You'll have zero chance of getting the fine waived so put aside the $750 now.

If they let you keep your license they'll put you on a good behaviour bond for 12 months. A minor fuck up (small speeding fine, stop in no stopping zone, failure to indicate, etc) means an automatic loss of license for an entire year (I think?). To be completely honest good behaviour bonds aren't really worth it with the risk of incurring a minor penalty, especially with how actively the police enforce road rules to generate cash flow for the state.

>Accept the 3 month license suspension and get your license back at the end of it, unconditionally
Better option IMO. They don't hang a 12 month suspension over your head, and when you get your license back it's all over and done with.

Personally I'd advise that you don't try and dodge a license suspension by driving someone else's car or just winging it. I mean, depending on where you live you could potentially get away with it. But if you live out west in Sydney or elsewhere with a lot of prowling road pirates you're really running the gauntlet. Getting caught means a two year license loss, thousands of dollars of fines, caught again after that, car crushed, possible jail time, etc...

>>26286398
Be extra-special-triple-double-super careful with any interior plastics. The plastics in these cars can be more brittle than ritz crackers.
They're fun cars. They all rot at the front edge of the rear wheel wells. You might be able to see from looking in the wheel well, or if you open or take out the storage bin and somehow look at that junction from inside the cabin.
Factory steering is recirculating ball; not ideal but it's not the worst recirc ball setup. Rotaries also hate sitting for long periods of time; compression of the springs behind the apex/side seals causes the springs or seals to stick. Sometimes, a bad motor from sitting can be revived by dumping a fuckton of WD40 or ATF in the carb while it's running (like enough that it smokes out your entire zip code, and almost stalls the motor).
Ghetto compression test would be turning it over with the spark plugs removed and ignition coils disconnected, listening for even puffs of compression.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26281331
Why tho

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26284175
A lot of those older VAG engines are pretty solid, the main things to look out for on the 4.2 in particular are the intake manifold flaps (actuators tend to fail over time, making for less low-end torque) and the coil packs (which can be retrofitted for more modern ones with a simple adapter kit).
Chain-driven 4.2 40Vs are a different story (they're a nightmare), 4.2 FSIs still need the occasional major expensive service but they're less likely to slap you with it out of the blue like the chain-driven 40Vs do.

This here, as much as I want OP to be whitepilled.
>Cars that are just ridiculously bad engineered so you need to jump to the most stupid hoops to get the job done (e.g. remove the entire fucking front to change bulbs)
>Customers who visit you on a weekly base with stuff that's actually nothing (e.g. "There's this squeeking behind the dash exactly between 45.1 and 46.4 mph")
>Simply not enough time even if you don't smell the flowers (e.g. "we need their head gaskets to be replaced by noon, customer will arive at 8:30 (he arrives at 9:10))
>Boring repetitive jobs that need to be done on a daily base (e.g. fluid changes and all the other crap)
>Customers who cannot fucking leave you alone and stand under the car with you commenting every single step and asking dumb questions
>Endless diagnostics and changing of parts thanks to electronic bullshittery
>Hands always dirty and full of nicks, shop too cold during winter, standing for prolonged hours, uncomfortable positions needed to reach shit

Of course I forgot the pic related...
On a side note: The prices for empty Hazet Assistents are a fucking joke. Brand-new they are around 800 bucks and even if you got a 50 year old one that's fucked and rusted to shit you're still selling for about 200 or so.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26294169
All the regulations I'm familiar with classify "stock" as factory options available for that car, not what that particular car had.
Couple examples:

The fox body cobra had a shitty ass spoiler that didn't do anything on the track.
The Saleeen spoiler actually works.
So the Ford team was able to swap the Cobra spoiler for the Saleen spoiler because it was a factory offering.

Because the 2000 Cobra R had IRS you can legally swap a live axle chassis in American Iron series.(surprisingly the wins are about 50/50 for IRS vs LRA).

Even the RGT was in-house. Ruf’s naming scheme is the RGT is their equivalent to the Carrera/GT3, and the RTR is the equivalent to the Turbo/GT2. posts.name: fujiwarastickershop.jp
posts.com:
>>26274024
I'll reiterate a couple of points and add on a few things from the last time I talked about it, a large reason we didn't want to work on it is because of the aforementioned but there's a large list of things that piled on top of one another and we just don't feel like doing it anymore.

- We're spending money on production that could be used for that sticker on other products instead. Pre-orders are gone, and we don't want to create a 6 week lead time (pre-order + production).

- I worked briefly with desuprint who informed me of issues with production, a large one being that Taiyo works in Inkscape primarily and the design would have to be completely rebuilt in Illustrator along with the white ink layer. desuprint also had the foil we wanted to do it on, however he has told me a while ago he is unable to reproduce it. The cost in paying him to print the stickers would be exploiting and underpaying him, or it would end up charging the customer out the ass. Paying over $10 for a sticker is stupid, and that's ironic because my store will only offer tracked shipping in the future and I apologize for any international orders because shipping is literally going to eat people's asses.

- Many things have been on my backlog for a while. In the past 6 months, nearly every original Taiyo design has been under renovation along with new(er) projects. I reflected over my FOTM drop and figured it wasn't something I wanted to force myself to do like I did before after Grandmasterslices gave me input that made me realize I was pushing myself way too hard and getting frustrated over nothing.

tl;dr no thanks, see you when the store is open someday.

>>26292636
I have done some horrible horrible things to mine, and as you would expect the has milage has gone from bad (15mpg) to worse (10-12.) Don't get a manual, they are fun but weird issues with the sizing of the TOB and clutch pressure plate causes the TOB to rub on the input shaft of the transmission causing damage and heating up the TOB and killing it prematurely. I think there are some hack jobs like sleeve kits for the input shafts and oversized TOBs but they are annoying. 1GR-FE parts are easy to find but things more specific to the model like the viscous coupling parts for the all time AWD transfer case for the manual transmission are a PITA to find. Also they are generally way overpriced. Mine is just a wheeler now which is okay I guess. Overall 6/10 vehicle.

I'm trying to chase lean and fuel trim codes on my 2005 sportage, 2.7 v6.
Bank 1 long term sits around 14.8% and bank 2 sits around 14.1, dousing the running engine in brake cleaner doesn't really provoke a change in either short term bank trim. Downstream o2 sensors occasionally spike above 1v.
Should the next step be new downstream sensors or getting a gauge for fuel pressure?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26289879
Put it in park, set the parking brake, then release the foot brake. The car shouldn't move at all. You could also set the parking brake, put it into park, and then release the foot brake. The order doesn't matter as long as you don't release the foot brake before you set the parking brake.
If you put it in park and release the foot brake and then set the parking brake the car will roll a little bit when you release the foot brake as the parking pawl settles in to a slot which can really wedge it in there if you're on a hill and make it tough to shift back into gear when you want to leave.

posts.com:
>>26292184
it's doubtful both o2 sensors are going bad at the same time. i would carefully check for vacuum leaks (buy or borrow a smoke machine if you can), clean your maf sensor, and run some strong fuel injector cleaner. possibly take your fuel injectors out and clean/test their spray pattern. since both banks are bad, that would make me lean toward the maf or a vacuum leak. i wouldn't just start replacing parts until you narrow down the actual problem.

1) Hit local hardware store
2) Acquire round hickory tool handle about 20 inches long and 1.5 inches in diameter
3) Use a thin, round wood rasp for the four grooves around the handle
4) Use a flat wood rasp to round rown the edges at both ends
5) Drill a hole for the lanyard
6) Sand down the entire thing with #100 or so grid paper
7) Cover it in boiled linseed oil and let dry for about a week
Ta-daa, hickory bonker for no more than 10 bucks if you got the basic tools at home.

In the 2,5 years I've owned it I replaced the brakes, oil and the two rear springs. I've driven around 60000km since I bought it.
My GF once had an E46 from 2002 or 2003 with less than 200k kms. It was a nightmare. Constantly lost fluids, engine was never running quite right without any clear indication as to what might be wrong, valve seats were leaky (replaced them right away tho) etc.
Sold it after 9 months because it wasn't even close to passing inspection. And mind you, most of these issues weren't visible when we looked at it.
TL;DR: Don't buy used BMWs from cockroaches, ever. You WILL regret it. Well maintened ones from older white people are usually fine and last a long time.

posts.com: Why is it that carburator throttles are mounted vertically on an engine and that throttles for injection systems are mounted horizontally?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Can I install tint (taillight/reflector) in 50-60 degree weather if I heat it up a bit with a heat gun? Should I head the piece I'm applying the tint to prior or just after, and how much heat is enough?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26281198
Both fuel and air flow into the carburetor but fuel, being liquid, works better using gravity to reach the valvetrain and combustion chamber, so the throttle in the carburetor has to be placed horizontally.
Fuel and air intakes are separate in fuel injected engines, so the throttle bodies are able to be installed vertically.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26285116
>>26285315
it's a flex plate actually, because it's just a piece of sheet metal that the converter bolts to and holds the ring gear vs a flywheel that is a weighted chunk of steel or aluminum. and no, it won't hurt it to run without the transmission and it won't start at all without the flex plate since, again, it has the ring gear. it might idle a little fast or unstable without all of the weight of the torque converter to stabilize it but it won't harm it.

posts.name: Bepis
posts.com:
>>26278689
>>26278696
There’s a few different types of extractors you can use. The threaded ones are like emergency use and you can grab the 2pk of them at auto parts stores for <$20, but after you thread an overtightened lug into there backwards, it’s pretty much done.

The other type of extractors are good too and can be used more than once. I think they’re easier to use with an impact wrench than with a breaker bar or ratchet, and hammering the extractor on works way better than trying to hammer a 12pt socket on like other people try to recommend. Also if you go this route, don’t buy the cheapest possible Chinese ones off Amazon because they’re not going to bite well or last long. The Irwin ones are solid but they’re overpriced if you buy at the auto parts store. There’s a brand called Rocket Socket that you can find on Amazon and they’re supposed to be really good, not cheap but not overly expensive like some Snap On shit but they will be a livesaver for years to come.

posts.name: Bepis

>>26290961
Try to find a $500 V6 model that’s rusted out or crashed or no title but has a decent engine and trans too, that would be your best bet. Plus if you find a cheap junker 4.0 Ranger for $1000 or less, you can pull your parts, then put a handful of larger good parts for sale like any solid doors or liftgate or wheels, and then scrap the rest of the car for a couple hundred bucks and you can come real close to recovering the money for the junker.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>26290343
Was in the hydrogen industry some years ago, I dont have the numbers on hand but someone can Google them if they doubt what I say.
Hydrogen is light (good) but really bulky.
At the moment there are 2 methods to store and transport hydrogen.
No.1 is pressurized up to 600bars, which is ridiculously high. It is a pain in the ass to keep hydrogen in this state, since the small hydrogen molecule can pass through nearly any material. Also a large amount (I belive it was 15% or so) of the total stored energy is needed to even pressurize the gas. Also these hydrogen tanks are still bulky and take a lot of space (they should be great for short to mid ranged trucking and maybe shipping, but that's it)
No. 2 is liquid hydrogen. You cool it down to near absolute zero. Problem is waste now nearly half of the stored energy to liquefy it. With time the hydrogen will absorb heat and start to boil. The now gaseous hydrogen gets vented out of the tank, which is not so great if you want to park in a garage.
There are ideas to bind the hydrogen to other molecules like ammonia (NH3) but at this point you might just use carbonchains which in turn brings us back to conventional fuel.

There are some ideas to create a hydrogen paste, and I am hopeful, since I want to continue driving combustion cars.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>26290622
>you can extend the range on a FCEV more easily than a BEV since fuel cells aren't literal boat anchors like batteries
Except packaging 5.6kg of hydrogen (~187kWh, 480 Wh/mi, 390 mile range) into a 180 horsepower FCEV RWD Toyota Mirai results in a car that is about as heavy as a Tesla Model 3 Performance, and that BEV with its 75kWh battery (250 Wh/mi, 300 mile range) has 500 horsepower and AWD.
BEVs aren't being 'forced' by any secret cabal, they're just better for how people use their cars most of the time. Right now a 5 minute fill up on hydrogen every two weeks at $80 just isn't worth the price premium vs charging at home for $10, or occasionally spending $10 to put 100 miles of range in at a fast charger in 10 minutes.

Would being able to 'fill up' completely in 5 minutes be nice? Sure. But most people don't drive 600+ miles in a day that often, especially not without making at least one longer stop. Is the charging times at 250kW stations still not ideal if you need to add more than 100 miles of range? Yes, but its less common an issue than /o/ wants to pretend.
BEVs issues still largely stem just from lack of appropriate infrastructure, but they're way closer to solving those problems than FCEVs, and its more likely that batteries improve right now than hydrogen storage gets easier or becomes cost equivalent to driving a BEV.

>>26291423
Yes, the 'paste' or 'tape' concepts would still use fuel cells, they just make the storage and delivery of the hydrogen a bit easier. Their downside is they reduce the efficiency of the system, and make things more complex since the car would need to store the depleted tape or paste and then expel it to be 'recharged'.
With that issue Micro Flow Battery tech probably makes more sense.

Flow batteries have all the advantage hydrogen offers in terms of being able to store energy whenever it is available, and refill the full capacity extremely quickly.
But the charge / discharge is more efficient, and the storage is much less problematic. Still doesn't really make sense as a daily solution, but would potentially be an alternative on a track.

>>26291877
Its like this anon. Hydrogen isn't a magic bullet to save ICE.

A kilogram of hydrogen stores about the same energy as a gallon of gasoline. 33.4 kWh vs 33.7 kWh.
But hydrogen can't be stored in a gas tank. It has to be stored in pressure vessels.
That's what those big yellow things are in the picture, and there's actually a third obscured behind the electric motor at the back.
Those tanks that take up all the space that in a gas car would be the transmission tunnel or an FR car, fuel tank, and rear-transmission or a MR car, all three combined store 5.6kg of hydrogen.
For an internal combustion powered vehicle 5.6 kg of hydrogen is maybe 180 miles of range.

But consider the packaging of an ICE car for a moment. Without seriously sacrificing practicality you're not going to get the 3 big tanks you need for 5.6kg into a car.
Say you come up with a cool design that puts a tiny 3 cylinder engine at the back giving you 2 of those 3 tanks for 3.7kg.
That's even less capacity, and it required serious compromises to the powertrain.

To fit more into a internal combustion car would require even more sacrifices. Its really only ever going to work for dedicated hydrogen ICE track toys or racing series.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26291960
>Hydrogen isn't a magic bullet to save ICE.

FCEVs are just objectively superior to hydrogen ICE, but you could have hydrogen ICE enthusiast cars that have all the advantages of ICE in terms of lighter weight, better sound and a traditional driving experience. No need to wait for charging or having to worry about batteries overheating. There would have to be concessions to pack the hydrogen tanks in there, but you could do it. A hydrogen sports car would probably end up looking like pic related with the entire ass end filled with H2. FCEV vs. hydrogen ICE isn't a one vs. the other competition since they use the same infrastructure, and if there were really demand for hydrogen ICE there wouldn't be any reason to stop it.

On the other hand, once the technology scales, hydrogen ICE could actually end up being the "cheap" option since it doesn't require platinum for catalysts.

Either way, finding space for more tanks is a vastly simpler problem to solve than kWh/kg of batteries or CO2 recapture (or expanding hydrogen fuelling networks). If manufacturers want to make an FCEV cuckover with 1000mi+ range, it wouldn't be hard to do, just like it's not hard to make a gas or diesel that can do it. VW even stated they're working on an FCEV with 1200mi range.

As always, advantage of hydrogen is that we won't be a slave to China. H2 can be produced completely domestically. We have all the resources needed to build more nuclear power, and hydrogen is the most plentiful element in the universe.

I fucking hate fat modern trucks as much as anyone, but as a '77 F150 owner I need to point out a couple errors in those pictures. First, the old truck in the first pic is 2wd vs a 4wd new truck. If you got a 4wd truck back in the old days it came with a factory lift. As an aside, compared to today's "it snows where I live so I need 4wd" in the old days 4wd trucks weren't even in the same catalog as the main product line. It was assumed normal people bought 2wd trucks, even if they had to sometimes go a little offroad. Then you had the special catalog for loggers and hunters with the 4wd trucks.

Second, in the second pic they're comparing a long bed old truck vs short bed newer trucks. Beds didn't magically get shorter in 1980. You always could choose an 8' or 6.5' bed. You can still get a single cab, 8' bed truck even if they're not big sellers. And the newer trucks in that pic are crew cab models which by default. People buy more crewcab trucks with tiny beds because it's just a way to have an SUV without driving the same car as your wife. I think the only truck combo you can't get any more is crew cab/long bed. They look retarded but they were a thing in the '70s.

>>26290508
>I typically I fall for all the bullshit I see on here about how half tons can tow so little
I don't know who's saying that. A modern half ton can tow more than a 3/4 ton of the past (on paper) though that doesn't mean you should ever be towing at your max tow. A 3/4 ton can tow more because it has beefier brakes, axles, driveline, transmission and engine cooling. You also have a stronger frame with a bigger wheelbase so you get more stability. The engine doesn't matter that much. Memestreams might be aerodynamic but they're definitely not light and most of the double axles models should be towed behind a 3/4 ton, same with livestock and heavy equipment trailers.

Trucker sucks because with modern tech the truck and route is tracked and monitored by corporate.

Back in the boomer days it allowed you to travel cheap and see the country. Take detours and see the sights.
Today the truck is gps tracked every second, you aint venturing anywhere off the route, and you aint taking an extra day to get somewhere.
No more seeing the country for cheap, just what is next to the highway.

Best days of trucking ended when technology to track every rig in real time became cheap and practical to install standard on all vehicles.

You are locked in a depressing box forced to get unhealthy sitting, fighting the bad eyesight that comes with being unhealthy since you need to see to work, while being a poor traveling dad with failed family since being absent is the worst strike against family.
If you get in trouble for drugs or alcohol it can cost you your career, so dont self medicate away the sadness either.
And when you finaly screw up sitting for 70hours getting cut off all day and get into an accident those insurance premiums for you and any employer spike.
Driving for a living is a trick because enough hours on the road lead to accidents, and accidents increase insurance costs so much your bills in your personal life skyrocket.
Only ride share or door dash crap or handyman employee running your own vehicle into the ground at the same time is more of a racket.

>>26279883
The reality is that if you're a company driver you can expect to make 50-100k a year depending on what company you're with, level of experience, how much home time you take, etc.

The big 200k/300k numbers you see quoted are owner operators. That number doesn't account for fuel, truck payments, insurance, tolls, maintenance costs, etc.

The benefits of being a company driver is consistency. If your truck blows up, your company has to eat the cost of buying a new truck. They'll also keep you working in a rental, so your down time is minimal. The downside is that the company takes a large portion of the money you make per load.

The benefits of being a O/O is that you make way more money. The downside is that you have to pay for everything yourself. Consider that when diesel doubled in price a lot of O/Os got priced out of the business and had to sell their rigs, and that many first time O/Os are bankrupted by major repairs such as engine rebuilds.

Being a company driver is still good though. For the minimal financial commitment, training, skill and effort it takes to drive a truck you get a big paycheque. You can make more after a 12 week course than people that went to university for 5 years. Since you can live in the truck you can also save a ton of money by not paying rent anywhere. That's what I did for a year and a half to save for a downpayment on duplex, now I get paid to drive truck and paid to own land.

Just keep in mind that while the job isn't physically/mentally demanding in the traditional sense, it will stress and tire you out from long hours. It'll also grenade your social life - how you solve that is up to you.

Go to the seller, tell him you want a "third party inspection", there's a mechanic shop down the way, yadda yadda, and have him drive it down there with you. Go on a ride along with the mechanic. The mechanic will drive the car, check the radio, look at the engine, whatever, tell you if it's a good buy or if there are any problems. If there are, then that gives you a talking point for price deductions. Pay the mechanic a couple hundred for the inspection, it's worth it.
t. just bought a 2012 bmw z4, had a third party inspection, the seller had to fix a leak the mechanic identified, saved me $1k, everyone was happy and it was all professional.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>26285323
oh it's an e60, those tend to get real transmission problems. I would have the codes read by a competent bmw shop first. Most of the time with e60's they need valve body seals replaced and a fluid/filter change and possibly solenoids depending on the mileage. Sometimes you do need to have the valve body rebuilt. But you won't know what's wrong with it until you pull up which code the transmission threw. But if it's shifting perfectly fine, no harsh downshifts/upshifts, not clunking when coming to a dead stop, has no delay when going into reverse and no harsh park engagement it most likely needs valve body seals and a fluid and filter change.

This. Plus, frankly, it gives the boys an easy out before things get even staler. Look, I probably would keep watching the Grand Tour for the bants and the cinematography, like >>26269327 said, as this point I'm invested as a watcher. I really liked some of the episodes, like China and Cambodia/Vietnam. Even the RV episode was fun.

But in line with the majority of other comments, Grand Tour isn't really sure what it wants to be anymore. The studio "chat show" aspect is gone, and it's barely even a "car show" anymore. (Although part of that is due to larger cultural problems, since EU, USA, and other regions are in the process of legislatively killing real car culture. 2035 is fast approaching; what will you do?)

The more recent episodes are just heavily-scripted "adventure" in foreign countries with a few improvised bants that just happen to (sometimes) feature a few commercially-available cars. And I might even be fine with that... but it's annoying how the international aspect is so WASTED. They should have been leaning much more heavily into the local cultural aspect, taking cues from shows like Travel Man or even James May's own "Our Man in Japan/Italy" series. (What? You went to Sweden and Finland, and didn't even force the boys to eat surströmming and salmiakki for a gag?) They could have even returned somewhat to their car-show roots by delving into each country's transportation culture. (How to people get around? What vehicles do they use? Who makes them? What are future trends? Take some hints from May's old "Cars of the People.") But no, somehow it's more entertaining to use these lands as a backdrop for some obviously artificial real-life Wile E. Coyote hijinks. (My favorite part is when the trio talk about "modifying their cars" as if Clarkson is out in the garage operating a welder.)

The beetle. When I was in high school in the early 80s like half the class drove one of these to school. They were fun, easy to maintain, durable, and really cheap. Engine blew up? The junkyard had a stack of used 1600cc engines for $80 each and it literally took an hour and some jack stands to do an engine swap in your back yard.

You could cut off the muffler and bolt on a stinger, run it rich and throw on a switch operated spark plug in the exhaust to shoot flames out the back. Or you could adjust the torsion tubes to lift it and make it an offroader. There hasn't been a better teenager car since.

380 will always be the cheapest mercedes, no one likes the engine

the m116/m117 engines have plastic guides that break, usually drivers side upper is the first to go, they also have plastic clips that hold the camshaft oilers on that get stiff and will fall off, replace them regardless of mileage

K/KE jetronic is a boomer boogeyman that no one seems to understand but people continually fuck with, either buy it perfectly running or completely disassembled, it is not complicated

K/KE-jet era mercedes are also generally not worth as much as the earlier w108/w109/w116 cars or the golden era w140 cars.

tl;dr decent cars but cars are not investments, if you want to make money working on cars, provide a service

over time less and less people will be interested in a certain model. That means any base trims, or any models or engine configurations that weren't especially rare or prominent will not become desirable.

Would buying a 1984 380SE be a good investment? No I think you could put that money and energy elsewhere

Would buying a 1987 6.0L AMG SEC go up in value? Absolutely because of the rarity, engine configuration, history, prominence.

You could probably store a 380SE in a garage for 20 years, and get back an inflation adjusted $12,000 - but you would have spent 20 years neglecting it and paying for parking and likely would have lost money all things considered.

Vehicles are not investments

If that pic is the exact car in question, to some boomer it may be worth something, "I know what I got" type deal. On the average used car market, no one would pay out the ass for a car like that unless they *really* wanted it.

My advise: don't buy it expecting to turn a profit. Personally, I'd buy it for the enjoyment of it. Looks like a funny Sunday driver.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26287545
>buying cars as financial investments
Stop. If by investing you mean hoping they appreciate and turn a profit, stop. You are ONLY going to lose money, especially if you're buying mint/good condition ones. If by investing you mean buying to have fun with the car and enjoy driving/owning it, then sure, buy whatever you want.
>wagons
Wagons are always sought after by enthusiasts because they're cool however the ones on the market are already priced in and it would be extremely hard to turn a profit on one. But again, stop trying to treat cars like the stock market. You are going to lose money every time. From an ownership investment, you will get a lot of attention from car enthusiasts.
>E30/E34
The engines that came in the E30s were and still are extremely good engines. BMW knows how to make a good 6-cylinder engine. E34s have a slightly bigger engine than E30s but are still very good engines. If you own either, you'll be very happy.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26289940
Mostly the same as any old car, these gens are very dependable and don't have too many major issues. To start, unless you are prepared to shill out big dollars for a 'collectors' car like an e420, or e500, or some early 4matic, look for the basic and oddball cars. For example, I bought an 88 300ce. First year of production, less desirable motor, less power, but still cool looking and unique. 123 coupes are in much the same place (slept on) but you can get a turbodesiel coupe. Or look for wagons or the basic sedans. Make sure it has been somewhat well kept, the real Mercedes killer is simple neglect. When you have selected your funnyduddy car, realize now that these are shockingly basic cars. If you NEED cool little gizmos and gadgets, buy 210 or 140/129. They are all also very slow and handle rather poorly. Not sporty cars outside the dedicated models (e500/420). Get beneath the car next. Dependable or not, they are all very old and seals and gaskets and hoses are not designed to last 30 plus years. Look for leaks of any kind, and assess if its A) livable or B) fixable. While you are under there, check for rust. Again, while this isnt a Merc specific problem, its a 30yo car problem. Next check the body itself for rust, especially around the rear glass and sunroof (if equipped) as well as other common areas for rust like the bottom and corners of doors and wheel arches. Now the Merc specific issues. Fuel system is somewhat temperamental, expect issues on 124s with pumps and possibly injectors (something i am dealing with now). M104s can be known to consume headgaskets, but that is fairly rare. Thats about it since I dont know too much about the diesels. These are all sub 10k cars, some sub 5k for high miles but dont let mileage scare you, my 202 is at 242kmi and is still going strong.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26286545
Bull bars typically mount to/under the bumper and then wrap upwards without any additional support which causes any force applied to the top where you expect it to provide protection (like hitting a deer) to multiply the energy on the mounts (like using a breaker bar on stubborn bolts) and the entire bull bar folds in.
That's why we talk shit about them being a force multiplier- they wind up causing more damage then they prevent.

A bull bar can be modified to provide legitimate protection but that is much more of an involved installation.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26268628
high pumping and line losses would make it very inefficient. a lot of the energy put into this system would be converted to heat due to fluid shear - before locking torque converters this was basically how transmissions worked and they were much less efficient than with locking.
also, since a modern transmission uses gears placed after the torque converter you can easily increase the torque to the wheels without increasing the max "pressure" or fluid shear within the converter.
the system you're proposing would have a direct correlation between line pressure and wheel torque assuming a static impeller size at the axle; to achieve similar wheel torque to a traditional axled vehicle i'm guessing the line pressure would be prohibitively high.

t. mechanical engineer

posts.name: Bepis
posts.com:
For anybody thinking about headlight restoration kits…

Pic related is the 3M kit for like $29 at Advance Auto. In all fairness, the one lens I had just started to buff up, but the driver’s side is before I touched anything.

In the end the passenger side looks pretty damn good, I think driver’s side could’ve used 2 more passed in the beginning.

Was probably an hour worth of work. Last time I ended up buying new lenses from RockAuto because they were only ~$70 for a pair of TYC’s and new bulbs, but they wanted $180 for this car. If you can find them cheap, like <$100, I recommend the new lenses, but these kits aren’t bad. I think next time I will remove the headlight assemblies and do it on the bench so I can get the corners easier and don’t have the tape. Also you could probably do it without the kit, it’s just a little ~3” drill adapter with 500 and 800 grit sandpaper, then a 3000 grit wet sanding disc, then buffing and compound.

How were the TYC’s? For the last car they had the little heart on RockAuto and were only a couple bucks more than the cheapest shit, and they fit like a glove.

I figure the resurfacing one last that long, like it needs to be waxed on the regular. But for $30 I was kind of curious to see how well a 3M kit would work, and I think the lady will be trading that car in fairly soon so we didn’t want to spend the $180 on brand new ones. If they were ~$65 like on the Chebby van last time, I would’ve gone that route because two new bulbs alone from AutoZone would be at least half that much.

>>26285508
The Craftsman socket rails are like the Harbor Freight but the metal is much thicker so they hold sockets like 5x better. I like rails because you can cut them to whatever length you need. The Craftsman rails with shallow sockets, especially 1/4” and 3/8” drive, will stay together really well.

There’s plenty of magnetic holders too but they will be built for a full set of 10+ sockets. I think there are some rails where you twist the socket to lock/unlock them, but that may have been a dream.

Milwaukee sells a swivel head ratchet/ socket set that I always thought looked like a good set for a bike. Pic related, roto head 3/8” drive ratchet with 8x deep sockets and an extention. I think you fsn get it in metric or SAE. Picrel.

The little booklet had extra 3M chemicals for long term protection but the kit didn’t come with any. I just waxed the damn things when I was done.

>>26290805
Depends, the green and red top barra have stronger rods, they're fine out the box for decent hp, (~600hp) standard upgrades are billet oil pump and valve springs, that's about it. The factory xr6 turbo makes between 330hp (~7psi) to 430hp (FPV).
But for the most part, factory turbo rods or LPG rods are desired over the NA, practically everything else are identical between variants.
By the by, the gen1 5.7 LS is 310hp out the box (Same production year as barra), so it's exceeded by the base model turbo barra at factory 7psi, and trounced by the FG-X XR6 Sprint at 440hp factory.

I have a AU falcon (intech/auto) that I barra T56 manual swapped from a Mark II BA Xr6, I have a turbo kit from a BF Xr6T to go on it, and I have a donor car with a green top (turbo rods) if i need it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26293961
I totally agree with you, it’s all about picking out the right amount of cam for the application and quality tuning. That thing is sick, however, it’s worth acknowledging that it is a built race engine. If you have different info then please share, but those stadium super trucks should all be running LS based engines and are quite a bit lighter than 7000lbs. It’s also being kept in its power band and nearly WOT the entire time which is where an engine like that is happy. On the street at part throttle I guarantee it’s a dog until you get in the upper rev range. Similar to how people bitch about the e92 M3s being gutless down low. Tuning can only take you so far when you’ve got an engine built to scream.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26294009
That truck is a AWD trophy truck not a stadium truck. It just looks small because it's missing the bodywork. She's a big girl. Stadium trucks use LS's as do most TT except their bored out quite a bit. Big blocks are sometimes used but they're harder to fit and can make too much power at lower speeds which just spins the tires and wastes time. An e92 is going to be gutless down low because it's an extremely small V8. With an American pushrod V8 you got an extra 2-3 or more liters to work with which helps a lot on the low end even with an aggressive cam.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26294022
Ah my mistake, TT are a whole other animal entirely. They are definitely big heavy beasts with loads of drivetrain losses. Something like a 6-700 crank horsepower coming out to around ~400 at the wheels is wild. I do agree with the assessment of the e92 being gutless, the S65 is very small compared to a run of the mill LS3, I was more using that as an example of how an engine that was geared for top end can be a dog for daily driving. The fact that the LS engines are much larger definitely helps with torque down low. All I’m saying, it is still possible to wind up with a lazy LS if you spec it to rev to the moon, they’re just more forgiving compared to a smaller displacement engine thanks to displacement alone.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26281079
The more difficult part when i did the change on mine was getting the end links in. Getting the old bar out and new one in was fairly simple.
Si springs can be swapped over as well. 10mm drop, front spring rate is 7% higher (144.2lbs/in vs 126.8lbs/in) while the rears are 32% stiffer (208.8lbs/in vs 158.5lbs/in). Should help with reducing body roll/improving weight transfer, noticed with mine that it feels a bit wallowy when being pushed hard.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26281787
Yeah that was my problem lol. Ended up unbolting the endlinks from the sway bar and bolting them to the control arm first, then the sway bar. I also thought of installing Si springs to keep her OEM+ but I want a modest drop, so I'm installing Eibach Pros next week. So far I've installed a Type R shift assembly, subframe brace, DC strut bar, this sway bar, and soon the springs. I'm out of ideas for what next. Maybe brakes.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26281892
Brakes are a decent choice. DC5R calipers bolt straight on to the knuckle and go well with S2000 rotors, another option would be the Genesis Coupe Brembos paired with Rogue disks. DC5 Creations has a remachined TL Type S caliper that also directly bolts on (OEM ones use an M14 bolt rather than M12), need to use the TL-S rotors for that.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26281957
They should all be plug-n-play for the most part, bias will be more towards the front but the ABS should be able to figure it out. Just a warning though, the DC5R calipers will be the most expensive out of everything, over $1000 for a pair. Genesis coupe calipers are $700 from SlickFab, and the remachined TL-S ones are $515 at minimum if you're getting new calipers (will be less if you send in ones to be remachined)

if pic related eldorado's are FWD so might be a little better uphill in snow but RWD is doable in the snow with the right tires and weight in the back. as stated salt will eat the car if dead set on daily in the worst salted areas you might want to ceramic coat the paint and fluidfilm the frame.
The engine and trans are longitudinal mounted like a RWD car so replacing accessories like alternator and belt are up front, 1980 was the intro of the 368, it has GM's earliest form of throttle body injection so there will be old ECM, sensors, cat that can fail and give you even less than the 150hp the engine had stock.
If into the 80's styling i'd say find a RWD 1978-88 gbody like monte cutlass regal. Some northen states/counties are actualy lax on emissions test often omitting anything 1995 or pre ODB2 and older. you could probably easily find a gbody with at least a mild 350 and overdrive trans that be easy to maintain and somewhat fun to drive vs the caddy

>Will 60s cars go the way of pre-war cars where everything pretty much has to be hand made because there's no aftermarket?

I know this is a long shot but I think it depends on the future of 3D printing and mechanical fabrication. If that shit takes off then I think old cars will be maintained by enthusiasts as long as gasoline is still available. If you can 3D print a crucial part for your car, or pay a shop a few hundred to make it, then things will be fine. But if that never happens...then yeah things will probably get way more difficult.

Either way, I think the market for 50s-70s cars will crash as the boomers die off. I'm 30 and yeah those cars are cool and I'd like one, but I'm not rich and realistically a 90s car would just hold up better.

The only way you'll get one for a SANE price is to find a shitbox from a customer who doesn't want to pay what it costs to fix it and do it yourself.

In order to make anything work, from what research I've done, I would have to disassemble the hub by removing the outer plate, measure the inner diameter, and cut something so it fits those dimensions. If a later wire wheel would fit, that would save a tremendous amount of time; if not, Plan A is a Packard or similar steel wheel. Plan B is the lexan wheels niggers use for donks painted from the backside to look like a period steel wheel. Plan C is now hope the later ones interchange.

You have an absolutely amazing example; but, if the money is too good to pass you may want to sell. I've noticed prices have taken a hit; especially with projects, and you could always get back into it with another when you've advanced your station in life.

>>26280728
I always have a plan; I don't go into anything without doing my research. LM7 may look at it for me and get 75% of the information I need. The other bits like "What rear end does it have?" are not things I'd expect him to find out.

The Series 80 cars; like the one I want, have either 4.45:1, 4.88:1, or 4.65:1 gearing. Most enclosed cars got 4.45. California typically saw 4.88:1 gears. The 4.65:1 are like hen's teeth.

Whatever I do with this car, it's going to be mine for life. I'm going to use it to get groceries, go on day trips with the wife, and the occasional trip to New Orleans.

It's interesting that you also see the prices falling. I personally see cars like the one I want already taking a hit and I don't imagine the market for enclosed sedans recovering until the demographics change.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26291509
1984 500SEL, nice. The engine in that bad boy is using the classic K-Jet system (my 84 380SL had engine swaps with your engine). I can walk you through this.
> im going to prop up the entire FD in the car on a plank of wood, do the balance test with the injectors off, repeat with them on, im suspecting i have plugged injectors
Don't bother doing this. The KJet injectors are literally garden hose sprayers. What color are the injectors? Are they silver or gold? If they're gold, they're the newer copper types and will be good. If none of them are the gold copper types, just buy a new set of 8 from rmeuropean.com.
>i have an entire set of spare injectors, none of the caps are missing off the FD adjuster and i dont have any flat spots in the throttle swing so i believe the FD is good and likely not screwed with
Definitely DO NOT adjust anything on the fuel distributor! Please! Do not do this. These are configured from the bosch factory. Before you start playing with the fuel delivery system, see my next comment
>how common do these two piece intakes form leaks and is it the paper gaskets at the head or the rubber connecting seals
Air leaks are very very common and it's a CUNT of a job. If you have no record if it being done recently then I would start here. First, I would do a smoke test to see where the air leaks are coming from. There are a few areas where this can occur:
> Injector plastic/rubber seals
> Air intake "boot" (also get the new gasket for this)
> 8 intake plenum gasket donuts
> Paper gaskets that connect the intake top to the engine "V"
If you see smoke coming from any of these or worse, coming from what looks like the depths of the inner V, then you have to disassemble the entire intake system (you'll also get a chance to replace everything I mentioned above). This Benzworld thread has some of the pictures to show you how involved this job is https://www.benzworld.org/threads/1975-450sl-intake-manifold-full-of-water-coolant.3088072/

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26291509
>>26291726
Cont.
This thread is a good DIY of the entire intake plenum seal job. The car is a 560SL and uses the later engine but the intake and fuel delivery system is identical to your 500SEL.
https://www.autotrend.activeboard.com/t43370554/mercedes-benz-560-engine-intake-manifold-removal-gasket-and-/
This is honestly one of the worst jobs I have ever had to do and I did it TWICE because I fucked up sealing the plenum intake.
Also make sure the vacuum system is sealed up including the HVAC actuator and door lock system. All of those rubber connectors leak and should be replaced. Thankfully, these are cheap to do. Isolate the system as necessary using older rubber connectors and golf Tees. A hand vacuum pump is useful for these cars.
>Kjet
Once you've done this, next up is indeed the fuel delivery system. This system has a few components that can be problematic
> Fuel distributor "pumpkin" (the thing in the center of the air intake)
> Warm Up regulator
> Injectors x8
> Cold start valve
> The actual KJet "brain" that lives under the passenger footwell
> OVP Relay
> Fuel Pump Relay
Start with the OVP Relay. These often go bad and the consequence is the kjet brain stops fuel trimming.
Next up, if your injectors are silver just buy new ones. Don't bother trying to save the old style. IF you reseal your intake plenum, then you'll have the opportunity to replace the injectors (this was why I did the job twice. Reused old injectors.
The next job is replacing the gasket that regulates the fuel pressure in the fuel distributor itself. Follow this guide:https://www.benzworld.org/threads/cis-fuel-distributor-rebuild.2205337/
Very easy job. Again, DO NOT ADJUST THE SCREWS ON THE TOP! You're simply replacing the old gasket with a new one.
Next, replace the warm up regulator with a rebuilt one. These are more complicated and it's just easier to get a rebuilt. There's a guy in Australia that does this affordably https://k-jet.biz/

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26291759
Cold start valves have been know to leak. The easiest way to test this is to remove the valve, plug the intake with a big rag, attack the valve to a fuel line, start the car, and see if it leaks. If it does, replace it.
> Fuel pump relay
Lives up under the passenger kick well. Keep a spare because if this goes bad, the car won't start.
The forum community for these cars are ROCK SOLID. I recommend you check out peachparts.com and benzworld.org . The r107 sub forum on Benzworld has a very active community and a lot of guys are familiar with your engine type. Though also go to the w126 forum. Beware however, that all cars after 1985 use the KE-Jet system which replaced the warm up regulator with a more dynamic system. Advice for these two systems is entirely different and don't be swayed! Again, ask the r107 guys who this fuel delivery system.
> Good luck anon. My old benz was a money pit.

Double check your tranny fluid levels after the engine warms up. The torque converter holds quite a lot of fluid as well. Your 2-3 shift delay is probably caused by low fluid. Getting the levels in these is a pain in the ass and needs to be done with a fully hot engine on level ground. Add very small amounts, drive, wait a second, and check again.
Also only use leather, shop towel, or your fingers to wipe the tranny dip stick. Apparently lint from paper towels can destroy these trannies.

To be fair this board was a lot better before the /biz/ trolls started to invade it. A decade ago nobody gave a fuck if you spent a significant portion of your post tax income on cars - it was our hobby, it was only natural that it would get a significant portion of earnings. Nobody would shit on you if you owned and wrenched on a clapped out old shitbox like an old MR-2 or a Miata.

The last couple of years in particular have really killed this board IMO. Now it's just a pissing contest about who earns the most but manages to spend the smallest proportion of their income on their car. It's probably more a symptom of society and economics than just internet culture in itself, but it's really demoralising at how it seems to be killing this hobby.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Pennzoil NISMO GT-R invasion at 2001 NISMO FESTIVAL!

2001 was a rad year! It was a rare and unique opportunity to see all the Pennzoil-sponsored NISMO GT500 cars together. And let me tells you: the legendary american oil brand stopped to sponsor one of two NISMO official team chassis in 2000 JGTC season, but returned to 2001 for sponsor the ex-LOCTITE ZEXEL GT-R car, becoming the ‘Pennzoil ZEXEL GT-R’ that year. Different from the 1998 R33, and 1999 R34 Pennzoil GT500 champions, and even helping NISMO to win the 2001 season on team standings along with the sister chassis, the Pennzoil ZEXEL GT-R has been updated to ‘Castrol PITWORK GT-R’ for 2002, losing the yellow livery and the Pennzoil sponsor once again. So yes, it means that the Pennzoil ZEXEL GT-R is no longer around us.

Another curious fact, , is that the Pennzoil NISMO GT-R BCNR33 and BNR34 pictured here aren’t “original” cars, but replica based on other chassis. Respectively, they are the 1998 ZEXEL SKYLINE and 1999 CALSONIC SKYLINE repainted as Pennzoil-sponsored cars for NISMO’s heritage.

The original Pennzoil BCNR33 has the low-downforce kit and Nicos GT banner and sometimes can be seen appearing in some events, including the NISMO FESTIVAL itself. The original Pennzoil BNR34 however, has been lost. It was upgraded to ‘Castrol NISMO GT-R’ for 2000 JGTC season, but the car crashed in the first round, being replaced by a new bespoke chassis. NISMO took the IMPUL’s BNR34 late that year to replicate the 1999 JGTC GT500 drivers champion.

>>26259466
A historical racing team named French Speed Connection has bought a JLOC Murcielago and a Taisan Viper (can't remember which year), they're restoring them and plan to race them in the Endurance Racing Legends championship taking place around Europe.
Unfortunately most JGTC/Super GT cars have either been dismantled or stored in some warehouse/yard and collecting dust and/or rust. Sometimes they're put up for sale to free up room, or auctioned off (recent examples include the Jim Gainer 360/430, #666 Bomex Avanzza Vemac, one of the 986 Boxsters that ran in GT300). Another interesting case is the Dijon Racing GT300 Corvette, it ended up being converted to a drift car by Daigo Saito

Your gasket is leaking and burning up the coolant fast enough not to coffe up your oil or your head is cracked and it's doing the same thing.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>26292407
How little do you know about 4 cylinder high revving motorcycles?

A 4 cylinder 400cc bike is going to have tiny overbore cylinders, which means it's going to rev high and make good power up top, yes, but will be like a fucking moped at low revvs. This is going to drastically shorten the life if you just scream it around town, and it's going to suck to constantly row the gear box to avoid screaming around town everywhere. The 400 p-twin, on the other hand, will make less peak power, but it has two big meaty 200cc cylinders that product ample bottom end power to get you down the road. A 600cc 4 cylinder makes enough at the bottom end to still do what it needs but then goes full rocket ship when revv'd out. This is just basic physics and core engine knowledge, try reading a book sometime.

>>26286278
yeah so the eclipse and 944 are both sick cars, but they you need to have a garage and all the tools and you shouldnt expect to daily them. 944 is old and eclipses are very unreliable (electronics problems, you have to solder the ecu and shit), bit both can be sick cars if you can wrench good. theyre also hust really doffwrent cars. eclipse is a turbo/awd snow driving car. 944 is a fun little FR car.
another question: do you want to saily this car?
I've been forced to admit that its just better to daily a car from 2005ish or newer, unless it's a toyota. also, some of these cara are totally different layouts. so,
can you wrench?
do you want a daily or a weekend car?
what drivint conditions are in yohr area?
do you want a peppy FWD? a FR car that slides a little? or an AWD car for snow/dirt driving?
if you like AWD turbo cars like the eclipse, i don't see why various gwnerations of WRX shouldnt be on your list. you could get a clean bugeye/hawkeye WRX hatch, which would be way more reliable than the eclipse ans will gain value if you keep it clean.
if zou want a peppy reliable FWD car that makes nice engine sounds (like the prelude), you sjould obviously consider various civic Sis or an RSX, which you could also afford. now is a great time to buy an EP3 or an RSX type-S if zou can find one. 5th gen preludes are gwnerally trashed and rusty, but EP3s don't rust as bad and also make amazing dailies because of the cargo space of the hatch. Picrel was my shitbox EP3. You can also k20a3 or k24 swap them and then they become reasonably fast. Imo a civic or an RSX is a better choice than the stealth/probe or a beat up prelude.
If you want an FR car and don't mind the auto, Lexus SC300 would be fantastic if you could find one. There are also various other BMWs in this category you should consider. If you could find a 135i, that would be fantastic (10k should be enough). Also a Mercedes SLK R170 with the right motor/trans.
You should probably just get a BRZ.

>>26286226
My take:
-Nothing 80's, too old at this point to be a reliable daily without a major overhaul or a very pricey Boomer-owned garage queen or already overhauled and the owner wants to make a profit on his work. C4 Corvette may be an exception, but C5 is a better all around buy unless you specifically want a C4.

-Hard no to Jag, Audi, Eagle/Mitsu/Dodge

-90's Firebird/Camaro should be the cheaper end of the list that's worth buying, just make sure you don't buy a trashed one. Nice ones shouldn't be all that much as long as they're not collector-shape. Pretty much same for Mustang, though probably even cheaper all else equal. Pretty good time to buy a 90's Mustang honestly.

-C5 Vette is always a good decision, now is a pretty good time to buy as C8 buyers are unloading their old Vettes and more Boomers age out of driving them every year and prices cascade downward every time a new one comes out.

-E46 BMW can be a good decision if you get the 330 or 325 and they are rock bottom. If you can snag a 1 or 2 owner one that the most recent owner has owned for like 10 years and took care of, with just a couple of critical checks it can be super solid. Rear subframe and overflow coolant tank are two of the big ones people talk about.

-BRZ and 350/370z can all be OK, but it's TOUGH to find a non-clapped out one. Don't sleep on a G35/37 Coupe or Sedan, either, a G35 Sedan is kind of a Japanese BMW 3 series IMO. My dad had a G35 sedan and that was a nice car to drive, honestly I was reminded of it when I drove an R34 GT-R (not power-wise, but overall feel of everything).

-Lincoln LS are DIRT CHEAP, not very sporty, but DIRT CHEAP. Possibly an underrated car nowadays, they were very expensive back when they were new. Probably the least sporty on this list, but if you just want a comfortable A to B, it's hard to argue with the price.

Here are my thoughts on your short list there. If i exclude something, its because I dont know anything about it
>80s or 90s mustang
Good buy, but not too much car for the money. Finding a stock one is getting hard too. Great aftermarket

>xk8
Another good buy, not terribly unreliable but don't expect the best. Fast, fun, stylish, and for 10-15k you'll find one with sub 100k mi

>c4-c6 vette
All decent, I think c6s are closer to 15-20 though. Finding a c4 with a stick and the right year is a headache fyi. Strong aftermarket for all

>e46 m3
Not at all in your price range

>944
Cool, but you could find 928s in that 10-15k range too.

>350/370
Memes aside, great cars, strong aftermarket, just can be a challenge finding a stock one in good shape.

>Lincoln Ls
Loved mine, well within your budget. Hell, buy two, youll need the other 5r55 trust me. Handles great, has enough power, looks good, comfy, but criminally weak aftermarket. Cooling system is a headache, had to bleed mine on a weekly basis. Simply replace all of it when you get issues. They are also the only car I know of with aluminum suspension thats susceptible to corrosion. I really want another as a third car so I dont have to rely on it.

>BRZ
Gay

>Turd gens
They were great for 3-5k, not so much now at 7.5-10.They are very hard to find clean and not been sitting for eons, and even harder to find with your preferred option setup. Most manuals ive come across are on 305s too.

>Ford probe
Absolutely sick car, fun af and dependable enough. Kinda tough to find, however.

>SC 300/400
Difficult to find, expensive, few manuals. Prob the most reliable on the list in terms of things not breaking, but when they do, its not gonna be fun.

I would add a r129 sl500 on this list. You can get immaculate examples in your price range and its alot of car for the money. 5l v8. 300~ish horse depending on the year, convertible with winter hardtop, and incredibly comfortable interior They are dependable aswell

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26288451
Fluid film has done it for me. Usually October is safe because it's rare we get a snow before then. If you're talking about the flash rust from completely bare steel, I use rust reformer paint, or undercoating. If you use the undercoating you better be 100% sure that you cleaned that rust spot off entirely though....that's why I just keep a can of rust reformer in the garage. The paint will stay on all summer and the fluid film will keep the steel clean during winter. It's a total of maybe 7-10 hours a year, and that's being generous.

>>26288390
I live in midwest and went on an autistic fact finding mission about this recently. I bought an old f-150 I wanted to keep fresh. The truck has almost no rust compared to most of that vintage I see. Whoever, owned it before applied some sort of rust coating that did a really good job. Maybe the dealership did it. A thin black rust proofing.

from my research,
>Avoid rubberizing coating like the plague. water will be trapped between the coating and frame.
>fluid film/oil is the best thing for most cars that requires no prep. Although, if you oil a flaking rust spot that rust can just fall apart and break apart.
>get fluid into the front fenders
>spray wd-40 at the bottom of the door wells

For surface rust and not serious rot use rustoleum rusty metal primer cut with 50% acetone. can spray directly onto rust. thinned out with acetone it will penetrate deep into rust and cure into a super hard layer. I am working on undercoating both my cars with rusty metal primer. I was too busy to get it done this winter.

>>26277388
Seems like a good bunch of classic OVGRBR stages on it. It's going to be fun.
Some notes for the drivers that haven't driven on these stages before:
> UK Sprint Extreme
Strongly recommend reccing this one at least once. It's a very deceptive stage, and a few calls that frankly don't work too well with RBR's system. (Talking about the late left three call that is just past a gated junction you are supposed to pass later in the other direction.)
For the rest, it is a rather punishing stage where it is all too easy to wreck out when going off course.
>Northumbria
Pay utmost attention in the second half, in the narrow forest sections. One mistake, and you will most likely need a CFH to continue. The many ditches in the corners mean that it is also easy to flip the car here.
>Sherwood Forest I and II
The classic OVGRBR stages that have been run in every season so far. These are amongst the best RBR gravel stages, but they are very technical, and very daunting on your first go around them. It's all about getting in a good flow here, and to pay perfect attention to the pacenotes and when you can cut, as these stages have all too many obstacles just on the side of the narrow roads. You go off here, and you will most likely hit a few rocks or logs. I wouldn't try to cut anything here apart from when the co-driver tells you to do so, even in the easiest corners here. It's a tough stage, but very satisfying to get right.
The rest of the stages shouldn't be any tougher than stages earlier this championship.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26291735
The handbrake is used only in specific situations where you need to get the rear end to slide but you don't have enough room to whip the car side-to-side. If you just rip it willy nilly the car will spin. You need the rear wheels' thrust to drift, slowing them down with the handbrake will cause you to crash.

A normal drift is simply accomplished by approaching a corner as if you were gonna take it normally, but instead of coasting to the apex and laying on the power afterwards, you get on the power before the apex which causes the tail of the car to swing out, combined with the momentum from you initiating the turn. The handbrake comes in if the turn is really sharp (like a hairpin) where you need to swing the car around over 90 degrees in one motion and don't have enough road to start wide. Even so you actually rip the handbrake while still travelling in a straight line, and you need to clutch in to keep the engine from stalling or else off the mountain you go.

Yeah, it was a really fun series, despite how I wasn't too used to R5 cars at the start of the series, as I would usually pick WRC 2.0. cars instead of them usually. I can see now why they are so popular though, the class is relatively competitive with all cars (even if the Fabia R5 Evo is the most preferred one, by the looks of it) , and it is a relatively forgiving class in terms of handling and sliding around the car.
Maybe it is due to the latest NGP7 updates, but the handling of them feels a lot smoother now without suddenly encountering snap oversteer or understeer. Even with a few mishaps there and there (cough, cough, falling for snow tires during the Alpes Rally), it has to be the first time I finished a series without scoring a single stage DNF, and consistency really seemed to pay off at the end.
That last rally went especially smooth for me, but that's probably since those British gravel stages always seem to click well with me.
Was good to see too that the stage times became closer in the field as the series went on.
That said, pushing those cars hard is a lot of fun, so I'll try driving em more in the future.
As for the chill non-series rallies, I'd be up for it, as long I got the time for them. Would be fun driving some of the oldest shitboxes in the game again. Would said events be open for everyone though, given since it isn't for series points?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26280696
For starters, rally is all about experience, confidence and knowing (your own) limits.
As someone who basically only plays rally racing games when it comes to racing games, you need quite a different mindset compared to hotlapping on a tarmac circuit. Hence why I am total shit at Assetto Corsa, but that aside.
First thing you want to get the hang of, is to find a pace for yourself to consistently finish stages without crashing. Might sound like stating the obvious, but given how it is RBR, and rate of attrition is usually high in events, finishing events without wrecking out usually sees you moving up the ranking. Doesn't matter if some hotlapping Frenchman on tarmac beats you and the rest of the field by a full minute or more, just focus on your own pace without crashing first. Once you get the feeling that you are consistently reaching the finish, start pushing your own pace and confidence more and more, bit by bit. As long you don't crash doing so, you are constantly improving on your pace.
A quick way to learn, is to find a car and stage combination you are comfortable with, and start getting a feeling for how hard you can push that specific car / set-up without crashing or spinning out. You want to get in that flow where you can push the car hard without having the feeling that you might crash in the next two corners. Being comfortable in the car is what you want, it's nearly impossible to push hard with a car that you have the feeling of that you can bin it every second. If I drive a car that keeps never understeering or oversteering the entire time, I also focus on just making it to the line than to push hard. On tarmac, you want lots of grip and decent performance in hairpins, on looser surfaces like snow and gravel, you'd really want to find the flow where you can slide consistently sideways without spinning or crashing out. Remember, tapping the handbrake at the start of cornering usually gets you in a good slide, that's what rally cars are for.

All 4 “diamond cut” alloy wheels had peeling clear coat and paint. Also started developing corrosion.

All four door handles had the chrome peeling off.
