The USB port in the center console straight up died one day and refused to work.

Bluetooth audio would drop and reconnect far too often.

Rear driver side heated seat would sometimes turn on without toggling the button.

Gas mileage was beyond poor.

I fought tooth and nail with Hyundai and in the end the only thing they rectified out of “goodwill” was the headlights. Everything else was denied flat out. The GDI engine issues were the final nail in the coffin before I got rid of it. Swore off of Hyundai’s for the rest of my life.

Note the .gov in the address. This information covers everyone in the only country that matters.
https://www.ftc.gov/business-guidance/resources/businesspersons-guide-federal-warranty-law
Generally, tie-in sales provisions aren’t allowed. These are provisions that state or imply that a consumer must buy or use an item or service from a particular company to keep their warranty coverage. Here are some examples of prohibited tie-in sales provisions.
“To keep your new Plenum Brand Vacuum Cleaner warranty in effect, you must use genuine Plenum Brand Filter Bags. Failure to have scheduled maintenance performed, at your expense, by the Great American Maintenance Company, Inc., voids this warranty.”
“This limited warranty shall not apply if the warranty seal has been broken, removed, erased, defaced, altered, or is otherwise illegible,” where a device cannot be repaired without such effects.

It says generally because the exception is if the tie-in sale is free. As in free oil changes, free parts from the service department, and free installation if the warranty requires parts to be installed by their service department. >>26292360
> Even the frustrations are fun/interesting to look back on in retrospect.

Not for me, anything but a smooth run doing something the first try is infuriating to me, especially when it involves uncomfortable temperatures (hot or cold outside) and I have something taken apart/exposed that isn't supposed to be exposed to ambient air (dust/humidity/etc).

I think the biggest thing with cars specifically vs. other stuff is the stakes are too high. If I fuck up an engine badly enough, that can cost thousands to unfuck. If I fuck up a broken $20 Laserdisc player, it's $20 max lost. I'll dive in head first to some sub-$100 home item that would end up in the trash otherwise, but when the stakes are high it's another story. Same reason I would be hesitant to fix a relatively new/still valuable iPhone even though I've literally fixed iPhones in the past when they were old and not very valuable but still usable (changing the power button on an iPhone 4S was basically a full phone teardown and I did it no-problem first try). It's all about the stakes for me, I don't like gambling on a multi-thousand dollar engine, especially when the mechanic has to pay if he fucks it up, eliminating all risk for me. Don't even get me started on things like doing suspension work when something not fully connected properly could have the wheel crash into the unibody and total the car or something. Hard nope.

They're rare because of young adults (18-25 y/os) buying them in the 2010s when they were still cheapish and could get financed by banks. They rust from the inside out (see link below). Most shops that deal with these cars are either fucking RETARDS or scam artists. Parts are going quickly NLA (stuff like roof drip moldings, oil filter housings, MIVEC cam gear/solenoid if its a 9)

https://www.autotorque.net/chassis-leg-replacement/

Just finance a Mk6 Golf R, you can get one for $10-18k. $20-22k gets you a mint one. Or drop $30k on a VB WRX and you'll have a car that makes 400whp on bullshit bolt ons and a E85 tune. 400whp is stupid fast for a 3200lb car.

I paid $12k for this car as a roller (broken oil pump, spun bearing) in 2017 with 62k miles. I spent nearly $20k and I could've bought a CTR/Focus RS and paid it off by now. It has 69k miles now. These cars get expensive fucking fast and will bankrupt you.

>midsize and fullsize are arbitrary dealership terms.

1/2 ton and 3/4 ton maybe since the tow rating and payload capacity overlaps depending how you option them, but not midsize and fullsize.

Fullsize trucks are still pretty much designed as wage slave trucks at their core and even the most poverty spec F150 or GM is going to be dramatically better as a work truck than a Ranger or Colorado, basically no matter what you're doing. Tacoma with 4dr and 6' bed vs. poverty spec crew cab F150 is an 1100lb payload vs. 1800lb, which is not an arbitrary or negligible difference.

At least in NA nobody wants midsize as work trucks unless you're talking about painters or surveyors or something like that because crews want the interior space.

Even if manufacturers offered options that increased payload/tow capacity few people would buy them because in many cases they're going to get used as offices for foremen or your guys break room.

Toyota didn't even have an actual logo until 1989 though each model usually had its own logo like a Crown for the Crown, a U with one star inside for the Cressida, a C with 3 stars on top on the Corolla, a C with one star inside for the Corona, and the Phoenix on the MR2. and Mazda's was just the name stylized from 75-91 when they came out with the short lived Eternal Flame logo. Had previously been an M in a circle. Nissan was in the middle of transitioning from being Datsun in the US to Nissan like they always had been in Japan, early 80s ones even say "Datsun by Nissan". Datsun actually had their red and blue hamburger logo in the 30s-50s which they brought back but changed to say Nissan in 1978. Some prior Datsuns had a D in a circle with a red and a blue vertical stripe.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>26286644
The thing is, are the number of crashes that people walk away from more important than the number of people killed?
The numbers speak for themselves, road fatalities and injuries are down massively since the peak around the 1970s despite traffic and number of cars having grown exponentially. We tried the whole "just drive carefully" method and it didn't work, people were dying en masse.
Plus you're forgetting that as people get used to safety features, risk compensation disappears. Someone in the 90s who recently switched from a car with no ABS or airbags to one with those things might drive more recklessly for a while. But someone born in 2000 will not drive more carelessly in a car with those features because he's probably never been in one without them.

>>26281622
I prefer the off-idle torque over high strung top end, I don't have to rev the piss out of my engine on every freeway on ramp.
Turbo builds wind up a being a game of min/max where people run 8:1 so they can crank up the boost to 28psi for some magic number the see on a dyno once.
I'm running 11.4:1 with 7psi and I can run on pump gas (not all gas station brands).

I'm running a 70mm tb, 80mm air meter and 42# injectors. With the stock A9L I get about 20 miles before the plugs are fouled so bad that it won't start- that's even with a green tube in the air meter that's suppose to be tuned for the 42# injectors.
So if you plan on getting crazy you should be ready for a twEECer RT or Moates Quarter horse (I run the twEECer).

A set of subframe connectors runs you like $200 for a good full length pair. Most I've seen for frame stiffening on a fox or SN95 is ~$600 for a stiffler's FIT system, which is honestly overkill and the only benefit it really gives you is letting you jack the car up anywhere along the pinch weld. So, $200 for connectors and maybe $300 tops for a competent welder to install them and you're good to go. If you need to go beyond that in one of these cars, you'd be going beyond that in any other chassis.
